job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good place no real problems
cons: None I can think of

pros: Worked on a local ground campus in Orlando. They have a small campus with underserved students. Many are eager to learn, others need more development in their writing. The management tries to stay organized and make graduation fun for students. Large people of color population.
cons: Not much con, rain of Orlando. The police like ways of one of the staff members. But it does feel safe overall.

review_title: Noncompetitive salary with a team of Micro Managers
pros: Time off and a Christmas break
cons: Salary, 401K, Management, work life balance.

job_title: Senior Career Specialist in Columbia, MO
pros:
Excellent team of people to work with
Kept busy
Supervisor very open to new ideas, process improvement, etc.
cons: Really needed to clone myself - i.e. needed another SCS in the office to share counseling duties

pros: Helping students reach their goals.
cons: Extremely poor training for the expectations of the advisor role. The parties responsible for veterans benefits will not train employees but hold them responsible for errors.

review_title: Ok place. Maybe better now with a new President.
pros:
Ability to make a difference (if allowed)
Ok pay and benefits
Nationwide locations
cons:
Management rarely listened
The former president was arrogant
Rip-saw strategy changes

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Jefferson City, MO
pros: Good hours for a second job. I initially taught online, which is very flexible, and later taught in the classroom. There is a set curriculum, but also quite a bit of freedom in how each individual class operates.
cons: Other online teachers tried to teach enough classes to make this a full-time job, but the salary and benefits make that difficult.

review_title: Solid pay but not a competitive salary
job_title: Recruiter in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Work from home 
A lot of autonomy 
Great supervisor
cons: Not a competitive salary compared to the market

pros: Small college, beautiful campus, potential to grow.
cons: Need more support of faculty

job_title: Regional Enrollment Consultant in South Salt Lake, UT
pros: Lot of autonomy and you feel like you are your own boss
cons: Low pay compared to market and there is no opportunity for commission

pros: Coworkers will be like your family and you'll quickly feel the team spirit. Most people take great pride in their work and there are a lot of great systems to learn to use. Some remote work flexibility.
cons: The pay is not competitive and the health insurance is barely affordable. Campus staff do not get off for the entire winter break like students do so a lot of employees have to burn vacation time. Parking can be annoying. Not all offices have secure entrances (keycard or keypad). No maternity/paternity leave benefits.

pros: Great people, great opportunities, great place to learn, good for basic level professional development.
cons: Lacks in mentorship training and culture, slow at implementing changes, and can be a little hard to stay connected.

pros: Very flexible undergraduate program, financial aid available, staff members are always available by phone or email and are very helpful
cons: Not very many graduate programs

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good leadership, great classroom size
cons: No cons at this time

pros: Nice environment, you learn how an office works
cons: Minimum wage is not a liveable wage

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: Not a hard job. Often given projects to fill up the time.
cons: Pay is what is it. Expect minimum wage.

pros: The benefits were good and the 401K was above average.  The campus is very nice and well kept.  The cafeteria food is actually pretty good.
cons: The culture really started to decline with the hiring of the new President.  When a new President is hired you expect a change in culture, processes and in  leadership staff.  You just don't expect for the wrong decision to be made every step of the way.  The wrong people were fired and the wrong people were hired and promoted.  The focus is going away from the military and veteran students.  The college is spending more on marketing and less on services and is starting to feel more like a for-profit school that doesn't care about the student.

review_title: President and top leadership is lost
pros: The college has a long history and some good (but eroding) benefits. Tuition remission is a nice benefit if you or one of your children are attending college.
cons:
Leadership is lost. There is a regular "urgent project" that needs to be done and a total lack of strategic planning. 
The benefits are constantly being reduced.
Very little communication from leadership, which fosters a super active gossip mill and secretive decision making process.
Pay increases have been eliminated. We have moved from 2% a few years ago to 1.5% to zero for annual increases. Everyone gets the same increase no matter how hard you work.
Layoffs and furloughs are rampant and the good people have started to leave this past year accepting jobs with other companies. This probably will help with advancing in a career, until you are laid off.
Many of the "great ideas" by the president and leaders have failed.
The culture is fear.

review_title: Change is fast, furious, and never-ending
pros: If you can find a way to stand out--get appointed to the right committee or work for the right director, you can move up quickly.
cons:
-- Astronomical health insurance costs. It costs me 1/3 of my pre-tax salary to provide health care for my family. 

--Poor communication across the board. Lots of finger-pointing and not a very good training system at all.  In fact, there is no training "system." What you really have to do is build relationships with the right people so you can call on them for their institutional knowledge when you need it. If you don't build those relationships, you're going to be lost.

review_title: The job that allows you to grow in your career and learn new things
pros:
-Learning on the job and the ability to try new things.
-New president has a good vision and the outlook of the college looks bright.
-Fun work environment with good people that are very talented.
cons:
-A lot of red tape to cut through when getting things approved in the upper levels of management.
-The industry is losing money fast, so some benefits could be stripped as budgets are tightened.
-Reorganization of many departments has caused some uneasiness around the college. A lot of things change here on a yearly basis, so it's hard to feel consistent with your job duties.

job_title: Admissions Event Coordinator in Columbia, MO
pros: Everyone (especially those in my department) got along well, creating a fun and competitive work environment that spurred creativity and high achievement. The departments are very interconnected, which helps each employee understand and support the overall mission and purpose of the college's operations.
cons: A few departments are set in their ways, initially  resisting new ideas. So change, or adaptation to it, can be slow.

review_title: Extreme underpaying, over worked, militant work ethic
pros: They don't often fire employee's easily
cons: The pay is substandard.  For a management position, they start some off at poverty wages of $28,000/year.  They also use a military style of work ethic and over work the employees.  You are simply a number and you better not have any original ideas or think outside the box.  Any type of originality is squashed and reprimanded.  You also can't have an opinion. You must do what you're told and that's it.

review_title: Friendly people, good work, great culture, and good pay.
pros:
Health, dental and vision, 403b, competitive salaries (Columbia, MO)

Flexible schedule - Management is very flexible.  You can begin work day as early as 7 am and end as late at 6 pm, giving you flexibility on arrival and end of work day.  Some people even shift their schedules with different activities throughout the year.  As long as you where you need to be on time (meetings etc.) your work gets done, and you work your 40 hours, they are very understading and reasonable.

Everyone is extremely friendly and the work environment is great.  A good sign of this was the campus tour within the first several weeks of starting and new employee orientation for the quarter.  The tour took all the new employees around the campus and explained what every department did, so that we would all be familiar with our new workplace.  The employee orientation talked about benefits, the workplace, and all the department heads welcomed the new employees.  Hard work is encouraged and praised.  Accomplishments, both personal and department wide are consistently celebrated.  There are lots of events throughout the year for mignling with faculty, staff and students and opportunities for professional development.  Great speakers and conferences are happening all the time.  There is also the opportunity to travel to other campuses, other departments or job related conferences every year in order to learn more about the college.  Professional development on the job as well.  I am always learning new skills and developing the ones I have further.  I feel my ideas are being hear, and that my opinions matter.

There are great benefits here.  Aside from insurance and retirement, there are great on campus benefits.  Dulany hall is extremely affordable and offer a lot of variety of food and is right on campus.  It's nice not having to leave, bring my lunch, or pay extremely high prices for food.  The gym is available to all employees and 1 guest free of charge.  All employees receive a pass to all athletic events for them and 3 guests, free of charge.  The school spirit here is great.
cons: Always professional dress (which isn't really a con).  Denim Fridays are only available sometimes and only with a donation to a charity of $25. (I don't really think this is a con, since this means all faculty and staff look professional and we are helping a great cause)

job_title: Financial Aid Specialist in Columbia, MO
pros: The department is typically quiet but friendly. Employee benefits such as free tuition, use of the gym, free parking, etc. are really good. Even spouses and dependents get either free tuition or discounted tuition across all locations. They also have good benefits and retirement plan.
cons: The culture has changed where it's more of a business/corporation than a family.  There are no more merit raises each year, but there is a tiered system for specialists I, II, and III that each come with a pay raise. The pay for this position is pretty low compared to other institutions.

pros: Over the past 5 years the Pros have become fewer and fewer to work for Columbia College as a whole and in Technology Services. One Pro would be the coworkers, however I have seen some of the most dedicated employees removed or quit due to the changes over the past 5 years. Work life balance is another pro. Plenty of sick and vacation time with the allowance of 160hrs of vacation to be carried over to the next year if on salary. Depending on which sub-department in Technology Services you may or may not have to be on call over the weekend and nights.
cons: One of the biggest Cons of working in Technology Services is the management. The CIO if very old school and will become passive aggressive with staff instead of resolving issues. Also passive aggressive behavior towards staff that present any situations that are different from the directors that are in favor with the CIO. Some necessary budget items might get veto'd in one sub-department because the CIO has taken a passive-aggressive stance with that director. While approving niceties for another sub-department, because the CIO likes that director. This passive aggressive treatment has dropped morale within the department as a whole. Another Con would be the low pay compared to the industry as a whole. Some positions are still considered low skilled because the positions have not been updated, yet these positions have been given greater and greater responsibilities managing systems. Some positions have not received a raise in 5 years while other positions have seen raises year after years. (Usually those people in positions that are in favor with the CIO.) Comments by the CIO regarding pay increases have had the following responses given as to why a raise was not merited "You have a spouse that works. You don't need a raise." Yearly evaluations are used as a punishment instead of a feedback. The CIO will add comments to evaluations that he himself as not discussed with staff individually all year. At that point little recourse can be taken to refute the comments. There is more stick than carrot working in Technology services. Under the CIO several directors have quit as well as staff do to the treatment and low morale. Until a new CIO is in place avoid working in technology for Columbia College. During this Review the Current CIO is still employed by Columbia College.

pros: I got to work in many student worker's positions from Utility Service Worker, to Administrative Aide at the Enrollment Management Division, to Resident Assistant for the Dorm rooms, and as a Student Assistant for the Grossnickle Career Services Center.
cons: The student workers' positions where limited due to funding and only on the basis of being a student register to taking classes at the college. I was fortunate to land those positions but the search was difficult due to lack of opportunities for international students such as myself.

review_title: The people are great, schedule is flexible and non-traditional benefits are good.
pros: Working here is nice because it feels like an extended family.  There is ample opportunity for professional growth and there are celebrations for staff that include meals and recognition.
cons: The health insurance benefits are expensive and coupled with the low range for salaries here, many workers are actually paid below the poverty line. Poor performance also seems to get rewarded.

review_title: Has great potential, missing connection between leadership and trenches
pros:
- Great people to work with who truly care about the mission of the college and success of the student. 
- Beautiful campus in a great location/town.
cons:
- Employees with demonstrated/repeated behavioral issues are allowed to remain. 
- Aggressive project timelines are poorly organized and executed with little notice/planning. 
- Overtime expected. 
- Connection to leadership/feedback loop not present.

pros: Tuition exchange program offers full in seat tuition grant on campus and percentage online and with other colleges within the program for staff and children. There's also holiday pay, vacation, and sick leave.
cons: Main campus executive management is still a good ol' boys club despite the changes made with the new President and his staff.

pros: Good benfits, Nice hours, 403B, some coworkers are amazing
cons: Pay is the worse! Very clicky If you're not in the "popular crowd" you will never go anywhere. Mgmt plays favorites.

pros: I have worked with some wonderful people, some of whom have become close like family. Professional development opportunities and Friday jean days are a plus. We also have such a gorgeous campus!
cons: Low salary (and minimal to no raises each year), lack of growth opportunities, constant changing organizational structure, and lack of transparency within the organization

pros: Flexible and open. They don't have a thousand rules like other places. They leave it up to the people who actually have degrees in the fields they instruct.
cons: Little chance for growth

review_title: I'm not opposed to change but . . .
job_title: Military Services Coordinator in Columbia, MO
pros: There are still several benefits intact with Columbia College but due to the recent (last year to year and one half) changes within upper Administration there are innumerable changes and what used to be a solid and "safe" place of employment has become somewhat unsure.
cons: Too many changes and not enough stability for employees that have been with the instition for a length of time

pros: great insurance plans and prices, very great atmosphere, student centered environment, faculty seem to really care about the students they teach
cons: lack of upward mobility, very rigid organizational structure, pay scale not on par with other colleges and universities in the area.

review_title: Great place to learn and grow
pros: Plenty of work to get to know new technologies. Friendly environment.
cons: Low pay. Politics in higher management sometimes creates hindrances to progress. No training.

pros:
The benefits are great. Healthcare and gym privileges along with
75-100% tuition coverage including day, evening, online and masters degrees!
cons: Because this is higher education position, there is not a lot of money to go around for the hourly staff.

review_title: School is way behind the times in view of marketing and sales
job_title: Campus Admission Manager in Murray, UT
pros: Their accrediation, How they worked with Military, They were private and nonprofit
cons: Board does not like change, they stay in the old methods, dont create new ideas dont embrace technology

pros:
Employee Educational Grant for online (75% covered) and in-seat classes (100% covered)
Graduate Educational Grant for online graduate classes
Great co-workers
cons:
Small campus with not a lot of opportunities for advancement 
Many changes are a surprise

pros: Used to be nice place to work
cons: Low pay, micromanage, loss of academic freedom

job_title: Student Worker IT Support in Columbia, MO
pros: Good environment, especially in the tech center.
cons: Nothing particular. Maybe additional opportunity for good worker and getting rid of bad slacker?

pros: Great company! Would work there again
cons: Nothing do not have any complaints

pros: Great coworkers, wonderful benefits, rewarding service
cons: Traditional and limited movement within work place.

pros: 75-100% of paid tuition for employee, spouse and children.
cons: Little to no upward mobility, inconsistent rules, low pay, and bad office morale. Extremely high turnover.
